section.name: Customize an Editing Template
section.span: Learn how to create a template with a custom layout.
section.p: Using the Document Type Editor, you can create straightforward document types. You can add and remove fields, specify their properties and rearrange their order in a list. When moving fields up and down a list doesn't really cut it for you, you need to define your own layout.

subsection.name: Define the layout
subsection.p: First, create a namespace and a type. For this tutorial, we'll assume that you have created the namespace "fancy".

Then, create a new html file in the maven project, src/main/resources/fancy/FancyDocument.html:
[ body ]
[ bool ]
[ title ]

subsection.name: Update project
subsection.p:
To get maven to include this file in the resulting jar, add the following to your pom.xml:
<build> ... <resources> <resource> <filtering>false</filtering> <directory>${basedir}/src/main/resources</directory> <includes> <include>**/*.html</include> <include>**/*.css</include> </includes> </resource> </resources> ... </build>

subsection.name: Update template
subsection.p: In the CMS console, select the node describing the plugin cluster (/hippo:namespaces/fancy/document). It consists of three parts

dl.dd: A description of the node type, used by the editor
The prototype of the document, copied when a new instance is created
The cluster of plugins that displays the input boxes (template plugins). We'll be changing this part of the tree.

subsection.p: The template itself describes a plugin-cluster, a set of plugins that work together. The top node ("a0d592bd-368c-46da-803" in the screenshot) describes the configuration for a ListViewPlugin. We will replace this plugin with the custom layout plugin:

dl.dd: Create a multi-valued string property with values "extension.body", "extension.title", "extension.bool".
Create properties with these names and give them the values "${cluster.id}.body", "${cluster.id}.title" and "${cluster.id}.bool" respectively.
For the other plugins in the cluster, replace their "wicket.id" values with the relevant "${cluster.id}.xxx" service name.

subsection.name: Share and enjoy
subsection.p: You can now export the template (see the Create an editing template addon tutorial). Build the project with Maven and you're all set!
